awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Adaptation: Evidence-Informed Promotion of Inclusive Climate (EPIC) at IUPUI
awd_abstract_narration:
The IUPUI ADVANCE Adaptation project will improve institutional climate and promote inclusive leadership practices to address inequities in the representation, retention, and advancement of women, particularly women of color, in the STEM faculty.  IUPUI is an urban, public, research university in Indianapolis.  The Evidence-informed Promotion of Inclusive Climate (EPIC) project will adapt evidence-informed equity practices to the unique context of the IUPUI campus.  The two project goals are: to develop strong, equity-minded leaders to foster authentically inclusive environments; and to transform department processes and practices to reduce inequities and improve climate.  In order to accomplish these goals, the project team will implement various strategies including: quarterly half-day workshops that will become a STEM leadership learning community; departmental equity profiles based on quantitative and qualitative data and processes and practices to inform departmental enhancement activities; and accountability structures and practices to ensure that new practices addressing gender equity are implemented successfully and that positive change is sustained. 

Project EPIC at IUPUI strategically integrates best practices in a manner that is sensitive to the needs of the IUPUI campus. The leadership training builds on the work of the University of Washington, which used quarterly leadership workshops to gather department chairs across the campus to discuss pertinent issues, capitalizing on the expertise of many individuals across the campus and providing a venue for the cross-pollination of ideas among colleagues in similar posts. This model will be expanded to include formal and informal leaders at multiple levels. The departmental enhancement activities build on the work of University of Colorado Boulder, where faculty work on departmental-specific challenges as a community of practice.  The IUPUI project will test existing ADVANCE models in a novel context.  Specifically, IUPUI is a core campus of Indiana University (IU), and the project team will share emerging best practices with the seven IU campuses, including the Schools of Medicine.  IUPUI is also engaged in the  NSF INCLUDES project called ASPIRE which has a goal of diversifying STEM faculty and promoting inclusive teaching practices.  The projects are expected to be complementary for IUPUI but also provide an avenue for sharing project results with other institutions participating in the NSF INCLUDES community

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Adaptation" awards provide support for the adaptation and adoption of evidence-based strategies to academic, non-profit institution of higher education as well as non-academic, non-profit organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching aim of Project EPIC (Evidence-Informed Promotion of Inclusive Climate) was to improve institutional climate and promote inclusive leadership practices so that we could increase the representation, retention, and advancement of women, particularly women of color across tenure-track ranks in STEM departments on the IUPUI campus. Twenty-seven STEM departments across six schools (Schools of Science, Engineering & Technology, Informatics & Computing, Liberal Arts, Public Health, Public and Environmental Affairs) were targeted for grant-supported activities. Two major goals drove this work. The first goal was to develop equity-minded leaders to foster authentically inclusive climates. Strategies to address this goal were adapted from ADVANCE efforts at other institutions and included, 1) Quarterly half-day workshops for school leaders at varying levels; and 2) Quarterly mentoring-for-leadership lunches for aspiring female leaders. In Years 3 and 4 we shifted the leadership development support to a community of practice model and complemented mentoring-for-leadership lunches with engagement in mentoring circles by women in STEM departments. We also integrated programming delivered by professional actors to extend our support for leadership development to all deans and department chairs on campus.

 

The second goal was to transform department processes and practices to reduce inequities and improve climates. Strategies aligned with this goal included, 1) Creating “equity profiles” for all STEM departments in collaboration with our Office of Institutional Research and Decision Support, and 2) Awarding Departmental Enhancement Grants, supported by robust assessment and evaluation expertise, to address opportunities for improvement illuminated through the equity profile.  Finally, we focused on implementing accountability structures across all policies and practices in to ensure positive results were sustained beyond the award period and able to withstand personnel and organizational changes over time.

 

Project EPIC was implemented during a period of significant change. First, the pandemic rendered the need to shift to online programming during years 2 and 3. Second, Indiana University and Purdue University elected to realign their programs into separate institutions (effective July 1, 2024) – shifting programs in Engineering and Technology to be affiliated with the Purdue West Lafayette campus and transferring programs in Science to the new Indiana University Indianapolis campus. Many of the faculty associated with Project EPIC activities were drawn into planning for the realignment, and some faculty elected to retire or leave the institution rather than remain with their realigned programs. Although there was a substantial loss in the number of tenure-track positions in this time frame, there was a slight gain of in the proportional representation of women on campus overall, and in the School of Science, the social science units in the School of Liberal Arts, the Informatics department in the School of Informatics and Computing, and in the PhD-granting departments of the Fairbanks School of Public Health. Similarly, there was an increase in the percent of URM faculty who are women across campus and in all STEM units except Informatics and the Fairbanks School of Public Health.

 

Project EPIC played a key role in advancing the importance of diversity, equity, and inclusion work among STEM department leaders. Throughout the entire project we engaged the Council of Deans in a community of practice around a year-long series of reading intended to strengthen equity-oriented leadership and advance policy and practice aimed at promoting authentically inclusive climates within departments. Ten STEM departments developed and implemented action plans aimed at improving departmental climates for women, particularly women from minoritized groups. The campus implemented a new "integrated excellence in DEI" pathway for promotion among both tenure-track and non-tenure track faculty, and the majority of schools have followed suit with adapting their discipline-specific criteria and standards to also explicitly value faculty activity that advances equity, inclusion and/or diversity. Training requirements aimed at preventing bias were instituted for all search committee members and members of the campus promotion and tenure committee. Our external evaluators reported that Project EPIC was construed as integrated with a host of DEI initiatives and efforts, rather than operating in isolation, which has helped to support sustainable changes across campus.
